concepts.concept_name: Types of relations: reflexive, symmetric, transitive, and equivalence relations
Composition of functions: (f o g)(x) = f(g(x)) and its properties
Inverse of a function: existence (bijection), finding f^(-1), and verifying f o f^(-1) = I

in_scope: Reflexive relation: (a, a) in R for all a in A
Symmetric relation: (a, b) in R implies (b, a) in R
Transitive relation: (a, b) and (b, c) in R implies (a, c) in R
Equivalence relation: reflexive + symmetric + transitive
Equivalence classes
Composition of functions: (f o g)(x) = f(g(x))
Composition is associative but not commutative in general
Inverse exists only for bijective functions
Finding inverse of simple polynomial and rational functions
Verifying: f o f^(-1) = f^(-1) o f = identity function
out_of_scope: Partial orders and lattices (Beyond ICSE scope)
Basic sets and relations definitions (Covered in Class 11)

concepts.concept_name: Types of matrices, transpose, symmetric and skew-symmetric matrices
Matrix operations: addition, scalar multiplication, multiplication, and properties
Determinants of 2x2 and 3x3 matrices: expansion, properties, and cofactors

in_scope: Types: row, column, square, diagonal, scalar, identity, null, triangular
Transpose: (A')' = A, (A+B)' = A'+B', (kA)' = kA', (AB)' = B'A'
Symmetric matrix: A' = A; Skew-symmetric: A' = -A
Every square matrix = sum of symmetric and skew-symmetric matrices
Matrix multiplication up to 3x3
Determinant expansion along any row or column
Properties of determinants: row/column operations, factor theorem
Cofactor matrix and adjoint: adj(A)
Inverse: A^(-1) = adj(A)/|A| when |A| is not 0
Solving AX = B using X = A^(-1)B for 2 and 3 variables
Cramer's rule for solving systems of linear equations
out_of_scope: Rank of a matrix (Beyond ICSE scope)

concepts.concept_name: Continuity of a function at a point and over an interval; algebra of continuous functions

in_scope: Continuity at x = a: lim(x->a) f(x) = f(a)
Left and right continuity
Continuity of polynomial, rational, trigonometric functions
Differentiability implies continuity (converse not true)
Chain rule: dy/dx = dy/du * du/dx
Implicit differentiation: d/dx[f(x,y)] treating y as function of x
Parametric differentiation: dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt)
Derivatives of sin^(-1)x, cos^(-1)x, tan^(-1)x
Logarithmic differentiation for y = [f(x)]^g(x)

concepts.concept_name: Rate of change of quantities and related rates problems
Increasing and decreasing functions using the sign of the first derivative

Related rates: applying chain rule to real-world rates
Increasing function: f'(x) > 0; Decreasing: f'(x) < 0
Critical points: f'(x) = 0 or f'(x) undefined
First derivative test for local maxima and minima

Absolute maxima and minima on closed intervals
Word problems: maximising area, minimising cost, optimising dimensions
Tangent and normal to a curve at a given point

concepts.concept_name: Indefinite integrals: integration as the inverse of differentiation and standard formulae

in_scope: Integration as anti-derivative
Standard integrals: integral of x^n, sin(x), cos(x), sec^2(x), e^x, 1/x
Integration by substitution
Integration of rational functions using partial fractions
Integration by parts: integral(u*dv) = uv - integral(v*du)

Properties: integral(a to b) = -integral(b to a)

in_scope: Area = integral from a to b of f(x) dx (when f(x) >= 0)
Area below x-axis: take absolute value of integral
Area bounded by curve and x-axis between two points
Area bounded by curve and y-axis: integral with respect to y

General solution and particular solution

concepts.concept_name: Conditional probability: P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B)/P(B) and multiplication theorem
Independent events: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) * P(B) and distinction from mutually exclusive events
Bayes' theorem: P(A_i|B) = P(B|A_i)*P(A_i) / sum[P(B|A_j)*P(A_j)] and applications
Random variables, probability distributions, mean (expectation), and variance of a random variable

in_scope: Conditional probability definition and computation
Multiplication rule: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) * P(B|A)
Independent events: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) * P(B)
Total probability theorem: P(B) = sum P(B|A_i) * P(A_i)
Bayes' theorem statement and proof
Applications: medical testing, manufacturing defects, reliability
Random variable: discrete random variable definition
Probability distribution table: sum P(X = x_i) = 1
Mean (expectation): E(X) = sum x_i * P(X = x_i)
Variance: Var(X) = E(X^2) - [E(X)]^2
Bernoulli trials and binomial distribution: P(X = r) = nCr * p^r * q^(n-r)
out_of_scope: Continuous random variables and probability density functions (Beyond ICSE scope)
